Butterflies soar using big wings and slow
flaps—about 20 times slower than the beat

To see how they fly with such odd timing and
equipment, scientists used high-speed video

to capture the body posture and motion of
butterflies flying in the lab.

Then, they simulated how each wingbeat pushes
air around—and how that changes with different

It turns out, butterflies rotate their bodies
with each wingbeat—that waggle helps them

Toning down the waggle and tilting forwards
pushes them ahead.

In this way, butterflies can get where they
need to go, in their own jerky, erratic way.
